topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack 1.0: Installation and Configuration for KVM Hypervisor

body.p: HPE Helion OpenStack allows you to manage a Kernel-based Virtual Machine (KVM) hypervisor and provision virtual machines. This document provides installation instructions for HPE Helion OpenStack on a suitably specified and prepared system.

section.title: Installing HPE Helion OpenStack
section.p: The installation and configuration process for KVM consists of the following general steps:

li.xref: Edit the JSON environment variables file
Preparing seed cloud host to create the seed VM
Downloading and extracting the installation packages
Install the seed VM and build your cloud

section.title: Verify Prerequisites
section.p: To ensure successful installation, please read through the following topics before you start.

ul.li: Review the support matrix for information on the supported hardware and software.
Make sure your environment meets the hardware and network configuration requirements.

section.title: Review the KVM deployment architecture
section.p: The following diagram depicts the required network topology for a KVM installation.
KVM deployment of HPE Helion OpenStack
For detailed network requirements, see Installation: Prerequisites.

section.title: Edit the JSON environment variables file
section.p: Before installing, make sure you have edited the JSON environment variables file that is required for installation.
For more information, see Editing the JSON Environment Variables File for Installation.

section.title: Prepare baremetal.csv file
section.p: Before installing, make sure you have created the baremetal.csv file that is required for installation.
For more information, see Creating the baremetal.csv file in HPE Helion OpenStack Installation: Prerequisites.

section.title: Set DNS servers
section.p: To set a default DNS name server for your HPE Helion OpenStack Commercial cloud, refer to Enabling Name Resolution from Tenant VMs in the Overcloud before installation.

section.title: Prepare the cloud seed host to create the seed VM
section.p: On the server identified to run the seed VM, called the seed VM host (or installation system), make sure that Ubuntu 14.04 LTS Server edition is installed and operating, as listed in Installation: Prerequisites.

section.title: Downloading and extracting the installation packages
section.p: Before you begin, you must have downloaded and extracted the required HPE Helion OpenStack installation packages. See Installation: Prerequisites.

section.title: Installing HPE Helion OpenStack
section.p: Make sure you have met all the hardware requirements and have completed the required tasks before you begin your installation. The following sections walk you through the steps to be executed on the seed VM host:

li.xref: Install the seed VM and build your cloud

section.title: Configure proxy information
section.p: Before you begin your installation on the seed VM host, if your environment uses a proxy server to access the Internet, configure the proxy information using the following steps:

li.p: Launch a terminal and log in to your seed VM host as root:
Edit the /etc/environment file to add the following lines:

codeblock.codeph: export http_proxy=http://<web_proxy_IP>/ export https_proxy=http://<web_proxy_IP>/ export no_proxy=localhost,127.0.0.1,<your 10.x IP address>

li.p: Where web_proxy_IP is your web proxy IP address.
Log out and re-login to the seed VM host to activate the proxy configuration.

section.title: Verify your installation
section.p: To verify that the installation is successful, connect to the HPE Helion OpenStack dashboard and the undercloud dashboard as shown in Verifying your installation.

section.title: Create projects for LDAP users
section.p: If you are integrating LDAP into your environment, you need to configure the Horizon dashboard for users. For more information, see Configure Horizon on the Integrating LDAP page.

section.title: Next Steps
section.p: Configure Block Storage by either deploying VSA or using HPE 3Par Array

li.p: Configure HPE Helion OpenStack tenant networks to use VLAN Provider Network.

HPE Helion OpenStack defaults to VxLAN to support tenant network isolation in a KVM Cloud Type. You can configure VLAN on HPE Helion OpenStack to enable communication with tenant's virtual machines hosted in a legacy infrastructure and/or based on VMWare ESX.
For instructions, see Enabling VLAN Provider Network in HPE Helion OpenStack.
Configure HPE StoreVirtual VSA

HPE StoreVirtual VSA Software is a Virtual Storage Appliance that provides the complete array functionality on top of Linux KVM environment without an external array hardware. It eliminates the need for external shared storage required to implement block storage features. It uses scale-out, distributed clustering to provide a pool of storage with enterprise storage features and simple management.
For instructions, see the Configuring HPE StoreVirtual VSA for Block Storage document.
Configure an HPE 3Par storage array
An optional HPE 3Par storage array that can be used to provide high performance Cinder block storage
For instructions, see the HPE Helion OpenStack HPE StoreServ (3PAR) Support document.
Configure a Swift Scale-Out cluster (Optional)

An optional Swift Scale-Out cluster instance of between two and twelve servers that is used for production cloud Object storage use (Scale-Out Swift extends the Starter Swift Cluster enabling greater capacity while maintaining any initial data present in Starter Swift).
For instructions, see the Scale-out Swift document.
Install DNS as a service (DNSaaS) (Optional).

Our managed DNS service, based on the OpenStack Designate project, is engineered to help you create, publish, and manage your DNS zones and records securely and efficiently to either a public or private DNS server network.
For installation instructions, see DNSaaS Installation and Configuration.
